news.title: VP Chiwenga, ED Power Struggles Escalate
news.content:
By A Correspondent Power struggles within ZANU PF appear to be intensifying amid renewed reports of a widening rift between President Emmerson Mnangagwa and his deputy, Vice President Constantino Chiwenga, over the partys succession plans.

ZANU PF Information and Publicity Director Farai Marapira on Monday sought to downplay the growing speculation, dismissing as false and mischievous claims that the two leaders are locked in a bitter fight over who should lead the ruling party beyond 2028.

Reports suggest a faction aligned with Chiwenga  the former Zimbabwe Defence Forces commander who spearheaded the 2017 military intervention that ushered Mnangagwa into power  is resisting the presidents alleged plans to extend his second term from 2028 to 2030. The proposed extension is widely seen as part of Mnangagwas strategy to delay or derail Chiwengas long-expected presidential ambitions.

Adding to the tension, insiders allege that Mnangagwa is quietly grooming his trusted ally and business magnate Kudakwashe Tagwirei, a fellow Karanga clansman, as his preferred successor. The move is said to have unsettled both Chiwenga and the other vice president, Kembo Mohadi, who view it as an attempt to centralize power within Mnangagwas faction.

However, Marapira dismissed the reports, insisting the top leadership remains united.

The relationship between the President and his two Vice Presidents is one of brotherhood, said Marapira. These are men who fought side by side for Zimbabwes liberation. They faced death together and continue to serve the country with mutual respect and loyalty.

All this talk of animosity and infighting is the work of detractors trying to sow alarm and despondency within our ranks. As a party, we remain solidly united behind President Mnangagwa.

Despite official denials, the MnangagwaChiwenga rivalry has long been an open secret in Zimbabwes political circles. Their uneasy alliance, forged during the November 2017 coup that ousted the late Robert Mugabe, began fracturing soon after Mnangagwa assumed office.

Chiwenga, who led the military campaign that brought Mnangagwa to power, is said to have viewed the arrangement as a transitional pact that would eventually see him take the reins. But Mnangagwa has spent the past seven years consolidating control  appointing loyalists to key state and party positions, while systematically sidelining Chiwengas military allies.

The presidents reported bid for a third term has become the latest flashpoint in their cold war. Chiwengas camp, comprising influential war veterans and sections of the military, is believed to be quietly resisting the move, arguing that Mnangagwas leadership has failed to deliver on economic promises and risks plunging the country deeper into crisis.

The factional rivalry has also played out subtly in public  through competing rallies, divergent media narratives, and growing tension between the partys civilian and military wings.

As ZANU PF prepares for its next elective congress, analysts warn that the unresolved succession dispute could destabilize the party and reshape Zimbabwes political landscape. Mnangagwas determination to extend his rule and Chiwengas persistence in positioning himself as heir apparent are seen as the biggest tests of the post-Mugabe era.

Still, Marapira maintains that all is well within the ruling party.

ZANU PF remains unshaken, disciplined, and united under the visionary leadership of President Mnangagwa, he said, dismissing the reports as wishful thinking by the opposition and Western media.

Political observers, however, believe the calm projected by the party masks a fierce behind-the-scenes power contest  one that could erupt into open confrontation as the 2028 election draws closer.

news.title: Cabinet Endorses Chipinge South Legislator’s Call for Community Share Ownership Law
news.content:
By A Correspondent| In a landmark development aimed at deepening economic inclusion and empowering local communities, Cabinet has approved the implementation of the Community Share Ownership Trust (CSOT) Framework, giving effect to a parliamentary motion moved earlier this year by Chipinge South Member of Parliament, Clifford Hlatywayo.

Hlatywayos motion, tabled in the National Assembly on 27 March 2025, called for the establishment of an Act of Parliament to make it mandatory for companies operating in local communities to allocate a share of their profits towards community development.

In his motion titled Establishment of an Act of Parliament on Community Share Ownership Schemes, Hlatywayo urged Government to ensure that the exploitation of natural resources translates into tangible benefits for the communities in which companies operate.

Companies must contribute a mandatory percentage of their profits  a proposal of five percent  towards the development and well-being of the communities they work from, Hlatywayo said. This contribution will be channelled into projects determined by community share scheme committees which will be established in each constituency.

Hlatywayo argued that corporate social responsibility (CSR) initiatives had failed to deliver meaningful development because they were voluntary and lacked accountability. He proposed that all sectors  including mining, agriculture, tourism, manufacturing, and construction  should fall under a new law compelling companies to invest directly in the communities they benefit from.

He also emphasised that the policy would prioritise local employment, recommending that 80 percent of jobs in companies operating in a given district be reserved for qualified local residents.

Our communities are the lifeblood of our economy, yet they continue to suffer under the weight of exploitation with little to no benefit, he said. It is time to ensure that companies contribute not only to their profits but also to the welfare and development of our people.

Following months of deliberation, Cabinet this week adopted and approved the implementation of the CSOT Framework, effectively operationalising the intent of Hlatywayos motion.

In a post-Cabinet briefing on 30 September 2025, Government said the framework forms part of the rural industrialisation strategy, which aims to ensure inclusive economic growth in line with President Emmerson Mnangagwas vision of leaving no one and no place behind.

Under the new framework, Community Economic Empowerment Trusts (CEETs)  which evolve from the previous CSOT model  will act as engines of local development. They will attract investments into agro-processing, industrial parks, and local enterprise development, leveraging agricultural and mineral resources in each district.

The Community Economic Empowerment Trusts will be critical vehicles to drive rural industrialisation in all districts, Cabinet noted. They will form a vital cog that attracts investments through partnerships, leveraging local resources and the Village Business Units being established.

Government also announced plans to amend the Economic Empowerment and Indigenisation Act to align it with the new empowerment thrust and harmonise it with the Mines and Minerals Amendment Bill.

The Implementation Framework will ensure that communities benefit from the extraction and exploitation of natural resources through revenue-sharing formulae. Companies already paying dividends to community trusts will continue under the current arrangement, while new entrants will be required to comply with the updated empowerment requirements.

news.title: Parliament Vows Action to Support Zimbabwe’s Women and Redistribute Unpaid Care Work
news.content:
HARARE  In a powerful declaration, Mashonaland East Senator Chief Ndicho has publicly pledged to drive parliamentary interventions that empower women and address the heavy burden of unpaid care work carried out by women and girls across Zimbabwe.

As legislators from now henceforth we have listened and we have heard, Chief Ndicho stated. When we go back to parliament, we will come up with interventions and policies that support the empowerment of women and in particular this agenda in totality. So to that end, we commit.

The Senator made this definitive commitment during a breakfast meeting on Unpaid Care and Domestic Work (UCDW), organized by a coalition of gender advocacy groups including the Womens Academy for Leadership and Political Excellence (WALPE), Womens Coalition of Zimbabwe, Padare/Enkundleni/Mens Forum of Gender and Oxfam in Zimbabwe.

The meeting, hosted at Crowne Plaza Monomotapa recently was held with the Zimbabwe Womens Parliamentary Caucus and gender champions from the Senate (the Chiefs) focused on how UCDW and Gender Based Violence (GBV) continue to limit womens participation in leadership and decision-making and how female MPs and Chiefs can advocate for laws that promote the recognition, reduction and redistribution of UCDW in the country.

To underscore the importance of the issue, Chief Ndicho invoked traditional proverbs, affirming womens foundational role in society. As traditional leaders, we value the role of women It is said Musha mukadzi, kusina mai hakuendwe and rurimi rwaamai because women are important and they have a key role within society, he stated.

This commitment from a senior traditional leader provides crucial momentum for a groundbreaking piece of legislation: the proposed Unpaid Care and Domestic Work (UCDW) Bill. The bill, developed through collaboration between WALPE and the Zimbabwe Womens Parliamentary Caucus, aims to formally recognize unpaid care and domestic work as legitimate labor and establish a national care policy.

The push for this reform is backed by years of advocacy and research showing that the disproportionate burden of UCDW limits womens participation in the economy and in leadership. The proposed legislation has already garnered significant cross-party support, signaling a growing recognition of unpaid care work as both a social justice and economic development issue.

With traditional leaders like Chief Ndicho now championing the cause, the movement to recognize, reduce, and redistribute unpaid care work is gaining critical momentum as the bill prepares for parliamentary debate.

news.title: ZIMRA Official in Hot Water for Allegedly Using Politician’s Name to Cover Corrupt Deals
news.content:
By A Correspondent| A senior officer at the Zimbabwe Revenue Authority (ZIMRA), Raymore Tafadzwa Machingura is facing mounting allegations of corruption, abuse of office, and illicit accumulation of wealth, amid claims he has been invoking the name of a prominent ZANU PF politician to protect himself from accountability.

According to a dossier seen by this publication and corroborated by a close source, Machingura has appeared before multiple internal hearings over the years, yet no decisive disciplinary action has been taken.

The source, who requested anonymity for fear of reprisals, alleged that Machingura openly boasts that his actions are shielded by political connections.

Documents reviewed indicate that Machingura allegedly failed to declare substantial assets as required under ZIMRA regulations.

The accumulation of such assets has raised questions within the authority, with critics arguing that the wealth appears disproportionate to his known earnings.

The source further alleged that Machingura leveraged his positions at key border posts to engage in illicit dealings.

He reportedly worked at Plumtree, Mutare, Beitbridge, and Bulawayo border stations locations often flagged for smuggling and corruption risks.

Each time he was transferred, the same pattern followed , unexplained wealth, and no consequences, the source claimed.

The dossier also claims that Machingura frequently name-drops a ZANU PF official from Chipinge Central, telling colleagues that his protection ensures no action will ever be taken against him.

This has fueled speculation within ZIMRA about political interference in internal disciplinary processes.

In response to questions from this publication, Raymore Tafadzwa Machingura dismissed the allegations as malicious and unfounded, suggesting they were driven by personal disputes.

I implore you to do your verifications first to ensure factual reporting. These are baseless accusations being driven by a bitter and jealous relative, he said.

On the alleged misconduct hearings, Machingura stated:

I kindly refer you to our ZIMRA HQ and enquire about the alleged misconduct hearings. I do not know of any.

Regarding the purported undeclared properties, he maintained that his records were in order:

I kindly request you to request for a copy of my asset declaration from ZIMRA and advise of any that are not declared. Again, I do not know of any.

On claims of irregular dealings at border posts, he responded:

There is nothing specific to respond to on this one. Kindly tell me of any specific irregular dealing that I was involved in and I will respond.

Dismissing suggestions of political protection, Machingura said:

I do not need any protection, but again you can verify with ZIMRA if anyone has interfered with their processes.

He further insisted that his wealth was legitimate, built over years of business:

I am open to any verifications concerning my sources of income. I have long established businesses that started even before my appointment at ZIMRA. You may request for my asset declaration at my time of inception (2010).

Efforts to obtain an official comment from ZIMRAs communications department were unsuccessful by the time of publication.

news.content:

ZANU PF Information and Publicity Director Farai Marapira on Monday dismissed as false claims that the two leaders are locked in a bitter power struggle over who should lead the party beyond 2028.

Reports have suggested that a faction aligned with Chiwenga  who led the 2017 military intervention that catapulted Mnangagwa to power  is resisting Mnangagwas alleged plans to extend his presidential term from 2028 to 2030. The alleged push for an extension has been widely interpreted as part of Mnangagwas strategy to block Chiwengas long-anticipated bid for the presidency.

Adding fuel to the fire, insiders claim Mnangagwa is grooming business tycoon and close ally Kudakwashe Tagwirei, a fellow Karanga clansman, as his preferred successor, sidelining both Chiwenga and the other Vice President, Kembo Mohadi.

However, Marapira played down the reports, describing them as baseless propaganda meant to sow division within ZANU PF.

The relationship between the President and his two Vice Presidents is one of brotherhood, said Marapira. These are men who fought side by side for Zimbabwes independence. They faced death together, and they continue to work together for the countrys progress.

All this talk of animosity and fighting is the work of detractors who wish to bring alarm and despondency within our ranks. Our party remains solidly united behind President Mnangagwa.

Despite Marapiras reassurances, tensions between Mnangagwa and Chiwenga have been simmering since the November 2017 coup that toppled the late Robert Mugabe. Chiwenga, then Commander of the Zimbabwe Defence Forces, was instrumental in orchestrating the military takeover that installed Mnangagwa as president  a move many in the army believed was a temporary arrangement to allow a transition to Chiwengas eventual leadership.

Chiwengas faction, largely composed of war veterans and military elites, is said to be growing increasingly restless over Mnangagwas refusal to honour what they claim was a gentlemens agreement for a power handover after two terms.

The rivalry has also manifested in subtle public gestures  from competing loyalist rallies to media leaks and social media campaigns portraying each side as the legitimate custodian of ZANU PFs liberation legacy.

As the ruling party heads toward its next congress, political observers believe the MnangagwaChiwenga succession dispute could define the future of both ZANU PF and Zimbabwes post-Mugabe political order.

Marapira, however, insisted that ZANU PF remains unshaken and united under the visionary leadership of President Mnangagwa, dismissing speculation of internal divisions as wishful thinking by the opposition and Western media.

news.title: NetOne’s Masunda Denies Hand in CEO’s Arrest
news.content:
The Chief Commercial Officer at Netone, Learnmore Masunda has publicly denied any hand and orchestrating the arrest of CEO Raphael Mushanawani, calling the claims a choreographed smear campaign.

The denial underscores the deep fractures within the companys leadership, which is now engulfed in a scandal involving allegations of corruption, misconduct, and financial mismanagement against multiple top executives.

CEOs Arrest and Disputed Charges

The crisis became public when the Zimbabwe Anti-Corruption Commission (ZACC) arrested Group CEO Raphael Mushanawani. He faces allegations of fraud and criminal abuse of office for unlawfully authorizing contracts worth $1.2 million for system upgrades.

However, the case appears to have significant discrepancies. Internal company documentation shows that only $272,000 was actually disbursed for these upgrades, and sources maintain the expenditures followed established procurement policies and had proper approvals. This has led to speculation about the validity of the charges.

Mushanawanis legal team has dismissed the arrest as a fabricated power grab.

Denial and Counter-Allegations in a Power Vacuum

With Mushanawanis contract up for renewal in November, attention turned to the internal power dynamics. Chief Commercial Officer Learnmore Masunda was identified by some as a potential successor, suggesting a motive for him to be involved in the CEOs legal troubles.

Masunda vehemently denied this in an interview. I have never harboured such ambitions and have no need to cause the arrest of my CEO, he stated. My main responsibilities are to support the Group CEO This is the task ahead of me, and the rest is just nothing but sideshows from our detractors.

He revealed he first learned of the allegations against him through the press and lamented the continued mudslinging.

A Web of Accusations Against Senior Leaders

The scandal extends far beyond the CEO, implicating several other high-ranking officials:

 Learnmore Masunda (CCO): Faces an internal probe into allegations of irregularities in vehicle disposal, authorizing questionable stock adjustments worth nearly $10 million annually, multiple sexual harassment complaints, and bringing a firearm to company premises to intimidate staff. Mr. Chidzodzo (Head of Procurement): Already before the courts over 17 missing Samsung Z Fold devices and implicated in the same vehicle disposal scheme as Masunda. Christopher Muchechemera (CTO): Accused of involvement in dubious procurement deals, including $15 million for microwave transmission equipment and $11.7 million for upgrades, where other vendors had offered similar equipment for as little as $8 million.

Sources indicate that NetOne Board Chair Engineer Mawurukira has taken action to block questionable financial practices originating from Masundas division, including discount waivers estimated to cost over $20 million annually.

The ZACC investigation itself has faced obstacles, including a reported incident where keys to an office containing crucial evidence went missing.

Amid the turmoil, staff have reported a culture of fear within NetOne, with intimidation and retaliation against those who question procurement decisions.

Mushanawani has since returned to work after being granted bail and has called for unity. An urgent executive committee meeting is scheduled to address the escalating crisis.

As investigations continue, the future leadership and stability of NetOne remain uncertain, raising serious questions about governance within Zimbabwes state-owned enterprises.

news.title: Top Zanu PF Officials Arrested Over Land Fraud
news.content:
By A Correspondent Two top Zanu PF officials in Harare South have been arrested by the Zimbabwe Anti-Corruption Commission (ZACC) over a massive land scam involving US$1.5 million.

Phinias Muchichwa (41), the ZANU PF chairperson for the Godfrey Chidyausiku district, and Anderson Frendson (37), the partys branch chief of security for the Josiah Magama branch, were nabbed for allegedly defrauding desperate home seekers through the illegal sale of residential stands.

ZACC spokesperson Simiso Mlevu confirmed the arrests, saying the two allegedly subdivided Stand 34 in Tariro Township, Hopley  a 9.3473-hectare piece of land owned by Sunshine Developments (Pvt) Ltd  into more than 200 residential stands which they sold for US$300 each, without the owners consent.

The pair reportedly preyed on fellow party members and other residents desperate for housing in Harares high-density suburb, cashing in on the ongoing urban land crisis.

They sold privately-owned land without authority, prejudicing Sunshine Developments of approximately US$1.5 million, said Mlevu.

Muchichwa and Frendson are expected to appear in court on October 6, 2025, facing charges of fraud.

The arrests come amid growing public frustration over rampant land scams across the country, many of which have been linked to politically connected land barons and ruling party officials. Despite repeated government pronouncements to curb such corruption, illegal land sales have continued to flourish, particularly in urban areas.

ZACC said investigations are still underway, with more arrests expected as additional victims come forward.

Sunshine Developments (Pvt) Ltd has not yet commented on the case.

news.title: Mabvazuva Secondary School Sees the Light as MP Mhetu’s Initiative Brings Hope, Development in Epworth
news.content:
Harare  September 29, 2025  For the first time since its establishment, the halls and classrooms of Mabvazuva Secondary School are now illuminated with electric light, marking a historic milestone for the school community. The official electrification ceremony, held on Monday, was a scene of immense joy and relief, signalling a new chapter of development for the institution.

The project was spearheaded by the areas Member of Parliament, Hon. Zivai Mhetu, and was funded partly through Constituency Development Funds (CDF). The event was further brightened by a surprise announcement from Grapnote Steel CEO, Weston Ruzvidzo, who pledged to fund the full school fees for seven students for the upcoming academic year.

In his address, Hon. Mhetu detailed the collaborative and transparent process that led to the projects success. He explained that a surplus of $1,500, accrued from a completed road construction project and assisted by the local board, was strategically redirected.

We called for a meeting with the constituency development committee and discussed our priorities. There was consensus on the electrification of Mabvazuva Secondary school, Mhetu stated.

The MP used the occasion to issue a powerful call for community involvement and accountable leadership. He urged parents and School Development Committee (SDC) representatives to actively participate in feedback meetings to dictate how CDF funds are used.

Parents attend these meetings and table their needs We prioritize the projects basing on the priorities as per the votes, Mhetu said, listing potential future projects like administration halls and computer labs. He stressed, If you dont attend, we wont know your needs.

Expanding his vision beyond the school, Mhetu framed the electrification as a critical step in a larger national mission. He drew comparisons to rapidly developed nations like China and Dubai, challenging attendees to envision a prosperous Zimbabwe.

We are fighting for the education of our children when we empower them, we have empowered the nation, he declared. We want to develop Zimbabwe and make it a prime destination My heart bleeds towards development and the empowerment of children because you are our future leaders.

Echoing the MPs sentiments, Grapnote Steel CEO Weston Ruzvidzo emphasized citizen responsibility, resonating with the Shona mantra, Nyika inovakwa nevene vayo (A country is built by its own people).

We will continue to support childrens development, Ruzvidzo said. Do not vandalise your legacy because the electrification of this school will benefit the community. You can now pump water and this is a developmental milestone worth celebrating.

The acting District Schools Inspector commended the initiative, aligning it with the goals of the heritage-based curriculum. As a ministry, we are happy when we have leaders with the vision of ensuring that they support the utilisation of available resources in schools, the official said.

The electrification of Mabvazuva Secondary is more than just a connection to the grid; it is a symbol of collective action, a beacon of educational hope, and a foundational step toward the communitysand the nationsaspirations for a brighter, self-built future.

news.title: “Kick for Life” Tournament Highlights Need for Discipline and Ethics in Youth Football, Says Kauzani
news.content:
Sports Correspondent

Harare  The inaugural Kick for Life Tournament, held last Saturday, brought together young football talent from across the community, but it also sparked reflection on the state of youth football, according to Hon. Ishmael Kauzani, founder of Crowborough Soccer Academy.

I would like to sincerely thank all of you for your participation in last Saturdays Kick for Life Tournament. It was our very first time organizing and hosting such an event, and I must say  it was both a learning experience and a proud moment for our community, Kauzani said.

While celebrating the success of the tournament, Kauzani raised concerns over worrying trends in grassroots football. Unfortunately, theres a growing tendency to prioritize winning at all costs, which has led to behaviors such as age cheating and recruiting so-called Jahbhora players  career dropouts who jump from one team to another for quick recognition, he said.

These actions not only destroy the spirit of development but also send the wrong message to the youth. Let us not forget: we are also fighting drug and substance abuse  a serious threat in our communities. If we, the mentors, compromise discipline and ethics, then we risk becoming part of the problem. We must lead by example, Kauzani added.

He urged coaches and teams to prioritize professionalism and long-term player development. I encourage all coaches and teams to register your players and issue proper licenses. Avoid recruiting players purely for short-term gains. Focus on long-term discipline, growth, and respect. Reject any form of cheating  it kills true talent. Promote professionalism in grassroots football, he said.

Looking ahead, Kauzani proposed the creation of the Kuwadzana Junior District League (KJDL) to formalize youth football development. I strongly recommend we begin working toward launching a Kuwadzana Junior District League (KJDL). This will formalize development structures and make our communities a force to reckon with in football circles, he said.

Reaffirming his commitment, Kauzani concluded: I am fully available and committed to helping make this vision a reality. Let us take this seriously and act now. Together, lets build disciplined, focused, and professional players  and stronger, drug-free communities.

The tournament has sparked dialogue among coaches, parents, and community leaders, highlighting the need for structured, ethical, and sustainable approaches to nurturing young football talent.
